title: 103_hr2188
content: The Act titled "Part-Time and Temporary Workers Protection Act of 1993" allows certain individuals seeking part-time employment to be eligible for unemployment compensation. The "Part-Time and Temporary Workers Protection Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude work that requires more hours per week than the individual's last job in the base period from the definition of suitable work for unemployment compensation eligibility. The amendment will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Labor will conduct an annual survey through the Bureau of Labor Statistics to identify characteristics of temporary workers in the US, their relationship with establishments, and with their permanent employers. Additionally, the Act aims to protect part-time and temporary workers. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans, specifically those who complete 500-1,000 hours of service per year. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans, specifically those who complete 500-1,000 hours of service per year. The amendment states that completing 500 hours of service within a 12-month period will be treated as completing 1,000 hours of service. Additionally, regulations will determine the extent to which certain positions typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans. Completing 500 hours of service within a designated period will be treated as completing 1,000 hours of service. Regulations will determine positions that typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans. Regulations will determine positions that typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans. Regulations will determine positions that typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. Amendments specify that completion of 250 hours of service within a certain period will be treated as completion of 500 hours of service for employees in specific positions. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans. The amendment specifies that completion of 500 hours of service within a designated period will be treated as completion of 1,000 hours of service for certain employees. Regulations will determine positions that typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for employees working less than full-time in pension plans. Regulations will determine positions that typically involve less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each pension plan. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for consideration of workforce circumstances in the plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for part-time workers in pension plans. Regulations will determine positions with less than 1,000 hours of service per year for each plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new rules for part-time workers in pension plans, specifically addressing reductions in employer-provided health plan premiums for employees working less than full-time. Employees are eligible for premium reductions if they customarily work less than 30 hours per week. The regulations determine if employment constituting less than 30 hours per week qualifies for premium reductions in a group health plan. The employer must ensure that the premium for part-time employees is not less than a proportion of what would be provided for full-time employees completing 30 hours per week. Definitions for this section are also provided. The regulations define terms related to group health plans, including "employer-provided premium" and "applicable premium." Conforming amendments are also made to ensure consistency with other sections of the Act. (A) Section 201(1) of the Act is amended to exclude section 211; (B) The table of contents is updated to reflect the changes. Sec. 211 expands the definition of an employee to include individuals who provide services to an employer under certain conditions. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1994, with a special rule for collectively bargained plans. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1994, with a special rule for collectively bargained plans. Paragraph (1) of this Act applies to benefits and individuals covered by any agreement by substituting the date of the commencement of the first plan year beginning on or after January 1, 1996. Plan amendments required by this section do not need to be made before the first plan year beginning on or after January 1, 1995. The plan must operate in accordance with the new amendment made after January 1, 1995, and apply retroactively to the first plan year. This does not mean the plan fails to provide benefits or operate as required by the plan.
